text:
from the front page of the New York Times:
*Russian Hack U.S. Agencies In Bold Attack* 
_Officials Admit Breach of Email Systems_
.. including the Treasury and Commerce Departments, and had free access to their email systems. Officials said a hunt was on to determine if other parts of the government had been affected by what looked to be one of the most sophisticated, and perhaps among the largest, attacks on federal systems in the past five years.  Several said national security-related agencies were also targeted ..

elements.text: from the front page of the New York Times:
Russian Hack U.S. Agencies In Bold Attack
Officials Admit Breach of Email Systems

.. including the Treasury and Commerce Departments, and had free access to their email systems. Officials said a hunt was on to determine if other parts of the government had been affected by what looked to be one of the most sophisticated, and perhaps among the largest, attacks on federal systems in the past five years.  Several said national security-related agencies were also targeted ..

text: It would be interesting to figure out how they conclusively attribute these attacks given that spoofing your identity is what hackers do.

elements.text: It would be interesting to figure out how they conclusively attribute these attacks given that spoofing your identity is what hackers do.

text: Based on the nature, scope and novelty of the attack, it is reasonably presumed to have to have been one of the very few most cyber-powerful nation-states.  More specific reasoning is not public at this time.

elements.text: Based on the nature, scope and novelty of the attack, it is reasonably presumed to have to have been one of the very few most cyber-powerful nation-states.  More specific reasoning is not public at this time.

text: All the more reason to not assign blame yet IMO.

elements.text: All the more reason to not assign blame yet IMO.

text: there are also "signatures". Nation state threats have certain trainings, techniques, code bases, etc. So even if traceless - there's usually clues.  This is bad news though. It took months to catch this - that said a lot of ATPs are low and slow...

elements.text: there are also "signatures". Nation state threats have certain trainings, techniques, code bases, etc. So even if traceless - there's usually clues.  This is bad news though. It took months to catch this - that said a lot of ATPs are low and slow...

text: I get there's signatures <@UPUBAM63X> -  but wouldn't that be the frist thing you want to spoof?

elements.text: -  but wouldn't that be the frist thing you want to spoof?

text: it does make sense that someone could misidentify a target alone via an attack's signature - but, consider that most sane intelligence agencies wouldn't report it unless it was founded. My assumption would be there would have to be other intel leading to make a determination like that.

elements.text: it does make sense that someone could misidentify a target alone via an attack's signature - but, consider that most sane intelligence agencies wouldn't report it unless it was founded. My assumption would be there would have to be other intel leading to make a determination like that.

text: At one point some of the groups would earmark their code and stuff. Kind of an ego thing I think?  In other cases it's probably less clear

elements.text: At one point some of the groups would earmark their code and stuff. Kind of an ego thing I think?  In other cases it's probably less clear

text: I didn't find that article when i went to NYTimes to see it. But i did see that Mitch McConnell finally acknowledged that Biden won!

elements.text: I didn't find that article when i went to NYTimes to see it. But i did see that Mitch McConnell finally acknowledged that Biden won!
